Latin usage of ‘phalanx’ and the term in Greek writers of the Hellenistic and Roman periods can be more specific: cf

title: counts twenty-two generals or independent commanders killed in approximately eighty-three land battles in Thucydides. Casualty figures for generals are not treated in P.Krentz, GRBS
Casualty rates for generals need not be a function of the level of technology. To cite a modern example, the so-called first ‘modern war,’ the American Civil War
is known for high casualties among general officers: 80 generals on each side were killed in battle and 123 Union and 135 Confederate generals received battle wounds
fought at a lower technological level, produced a higher ratio of general to total fatalities, 1:499—the highest of any American war, although only twelve American generals fell in battle
